item.title: China Races to Squelch Unrest as Signs of Economic Malaise Spread
item.description: Knife attacks and car rammings have officials unnerved about widespread societal discontent.

item.title: Vietnam Won Big in Donald Trump's First Trade War. Now, It's a Target.
item.description: The incoming administration has signaled that a backdoor that lets manufacturers avoid China tariffs could slam shut.

item.title: Syria's Christians Prepare for Holiday With Hope---and Fear
item.description: Islamist rebels now in control in Damascus have pledged full rights and equality to religious and ethnic minorities. Many Christians say time will tell.

item.title: Hezbollah Chief Says Assad's Fall Severed Key Supply Line From Iran
item.description: The loss of the route through Syria is a blow to the Lebanese militia and its most important ally, Tehran.

item.title: Ruthless Politics of South Korea Is Rooted in Cold-War History
item.description: The lasting effects of pre-democracy divisions help to explain Yoon Suk Yeol’s disastrous decision to enact military control.

item.title: India's Novel Attempts at Battling Deadly Air Pollution Are Falling Short
item.description: Residents see antismog guns and drones as “Band-Aid” solutions for a serious air-pollution problem.

item.title: The Hunt for the Assad Dynasty's Missing Billions Begins
item.description: The family stashed away its wealth over half a century of despotic rule. Human-rights lawyers are leading efforts to find the assets—and recover them for the Syrian people.

item.title: Brush With Russia in Baltic Points to New Flashpoint in NATO-Moscow Shadow War
item.description: Sabotage, warning shots, disruption of air traffic and dangerous military maneuvering are all part of the intensifying clandestine campaign in Europe, officials say.

item.title: Washington in Direct Talks With Islamist Faction That Toppled Assad
item.description: U.S., allies are pressing for a swift transition in Syria to avert a descent into chaos.

item.title: Venezuela Never Had So Many Political Prisoners. Seven of Them Are Teens.
item.description: The adolescents are among the estimated 2,200 people the regime said it arrested in July during protests over the country’s disputed presidential election.

item.title: South Korea Impeaches President Yoon Suk Yeol Over Martial-Law Decision
item.description: The prime minister is set to assume presidential powers on an interim basis. The constitutional court will now review the vote, which could take months.

item.title: Russia Begins Packing Up Military Equipment in Syria, Satellite Images Show
item.description: The air base at Khmeimim and the naval installation at Tartus had become synonymous with Russia’s intervention in Syria.

item.title: U.S. Ally Halts Fight Against Islamic State in Syria as It Battles Rebel Group
item.description: Washington’s main ally in the country warned that a power vacuum was leading to attacks on the group by Turkish-backed rebels.

item.title: Alleged Chinese Agent With Links to Prince Andrew Is Barred From U.K.
item.description: The Chinese businessman has been banned from entering the U.K. after intelligence services alleged he was trying to influence the British royal on behalf of Beijing.

item.title: American Freed From Syrian Regime Prison Was on Levantine Pilgrimage
item.description: The man, who gave his name as Travis Timmerman, was handed over to U.S. military officials after seven months in captivity.

item.title: Leaders of Rich Nations Are Deeply Unpopular. That Spells Trouble Ahead.
item.description: If you are in charge of a slow-growing democracy, it’s not looking good right now. Almost no leader of an industrialized country has a net-positive approval rating.

item.title: France's Macron Names New Prime Minister in Bid to End Political Gridlock
item.description: Seasoned centrist François Bayrou faces an immediate crisis as he leads a new government tasked with forging a budget.

item.title: Fall of Syrian Regime Exposes Limits of Russia's Global Ambitions
item.description: With Moscow’s money, attention and ammunition focused on its conflict with Ukraine, the Kremlin’s global power projects are in a state of slow decay.

item.title: Trump to Europe: Overseeing a Ukraine Cease-Fire Would Be Your Job
item.description: The president-elect told the French and Ukrainian leaders that he would want European troops to be present in Ukraine.

item.title: Trump Team Weighs Options, Including Airstrikes, to Stop Iran's Nuclear Program
item.description: Military action would break with longstanding U.S. policy of stopping Tehran’s weapons program through diplomatic means.
